A. TVET/HE organisations perform better their core tasks, firmly embedded in their environment
A.E.5. Number of curricula for degree, non-degree and short courses revised/newly developed

description.narrative: Degree: bachelor's, master's and doctorate Non degree: Certificate and diploma

comment.narrative:
Partners should give details regarding the inclusion of WASH course in the below or being additional. Is the total 3 or 4?
- By 2020, 1 short courses on WASH and CSA, water management/governance, entrepreneurship designed and implemented.
- By 2020, 3 new courses developed.

08-10-2021: 28 courses have been newly developed and updated (20 courses updated and 8 courses newly developed) These courses are: (13 courses in Rain Water Harvesting, 10 courses in Desalination, and 5 courses in Entrepreneurship)
Scoping study undertaken at all 9 universities - indicator 1.1. in LF

08-10-2021: 4 TMTs were organized so far i.e., 1 TMT on Entrepreneurship on January (reported here) and other 3 (desalination, SWAP (CSA), GIS/Remote sensing in water sector) beyond reporting period (will be reported next year). All academic staffs who attended the TMTS were supposed to work on developing the curriculum but it has been delayed due to COVID-19. The country were in lockdown and all universities were partially closed and class were offered virtually. Moreover, task force for curriculum development in each topic were formed but not yet produced their recommendations for curricula review.

Partners should clarify the total; 5,6,or 11?
- By 2021, 5 short courses on WASH and CSA, water management/governance, entrepreneurship designed and implemented.
- By 2021, 6 new courses developed.

title.narrative: A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: All Palestinian institutions have shared their motivation to purchase the needed equipment to facilitate research and curricula development in the field of WASH and CSA through official motivation letters. ANNU will manage the procurement for all universities through their procurement department. The process will start in September, when all staff are back to work from their offices.

dimension.name: Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility
dimension.value: Laboratory Library Resource centre Practical application unit Living lab

dimension.name: Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility Sort of facility
dimension.value: Laboratory Library Resource centre Practical application unit Living lab

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: An Najah University is leading the procurement of investment needs to all individual universities to comply with OKP guidelines. All universities have developed their shopping lists and motivation letters justifying the needs for the items they want to purchase. An Najah has assigned a procurement team the responsibility of implementing the process. Most of the goods were delivered to the recipient universities, and the process of receiving the gods by universities is still ongoing, which affected the payments process, we have a large number of pending payments that are not yet reported in R2 financial report. Procurement process has faced number of challenges imposed by COVID-19 pandemic and the Gaza war in May 2021. Vendors have encountered serious delays in shipments, which further delayed receiving lab equipment. Universities have used the investment funds to upgrade their labs to stimulate professors for new research areas, and involve more students in research projects. Other universities choose to use the investment funds for green houses, to practically demonstrate smart agriculture techniques Universities highly appreciate the investment fund part of the project because it covered funding shortage of the faculties to develop the labs and practical education

title.narrative: A.O.4. Number of organisations with a revised/developed system to registrate and monitor its alumni

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: All 9 partner universities have participated in the workshop and meetings to develop the system of registering alumni and organize alumni activities. working with alumni has been postponed until 2022, where it is expected to witness ease in allowing face to face meetings between students and alumni after COVID-19 pandemic has been managed.

08-10-2021: Four Palestinian institutions (ANNU, BZU, PTUK, PPU), have already started collecting information about graduates (in general) in faculty of engineering and agriculture. Other institutions will follow working with alumni has been interrupted due to COVID-19 Pandemic, but will resume whenever gatherings at education institutions are allowed. The project is planned to launch some alumni activities in WASH and CSA in beginning of 2021.

title.narrative: A.S.3. Number of students performing an internship or practical work

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: 18 Master students implement practical work at partner universities during their master research supervised by their professors who were trained in project TMTs of Desalination, Rain water harvesting, and GI and Remote sensing. More students are expected to take part in practical work during the Entrepreneurship competition journey which has started in the reporting period.

08-10-2021: Not yet started the actual work. It is expected each Palestinian universities will come up with internship/entrepreneurship model by beginning of 2021. After that student will start working on it. ,

title.narrative: A.E.3. Number of staff that have gained qualitative and relevant knowledge and skills to develop and offer the revised/developed study programmes

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The entrepreneurship including gender and governance training given in January provided a relevant knowledge for all training participants to update or develop new curriculum on entrepreneurship/gender/governance as separate course or embedded as a component in curriculum of WASH and CSA. The trainer have shared the useful material that help professors work on curricula development. Subsequent support will be offered by the trainer to follow up curricula revision process. Other TMTs on WASH and CSA conducted after the reporting period also benefitted professor to revised/developed study programme. But this will be reported next year. The number presented is only for first TMT.

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: Training has targeted academic and administrative staff from 9 different universities in a number of TMTs. Training has been implemented in face to face and online fashion.
These values correspond with indicators 1.6, 4.2. and 4.3 in LF

title.narrative: A.E.1. Number of (knowledge) institutions supported directly

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: An Najah University, Palestine Technical University, Birzeit University, Al Quds University, Hebron University, Palestine Polytechnic University, Arab American University, Azhar University, Islamic University of Gaza.

08-10-2021: The project activities were design and implemented in a holistic approach, where all partner universities have participated in the training opportunities of their interest. The scoping mission has targeted all partner universities in the assessment, all the needs have been considered in designing project activities. All universities have had representatives in almost all TMTs, unless the TMT presented was not their area of interest. During this reporting period, one TMT” Entrepreneurship, including Gender and Governance aspects” was organized in January 2020, where representaties from all 9 universities have participated (Gaza participants have joined through videoconference). The details of the TMT is attached. Please see report zero (scoping mission report for details)
Corresponds with LF output 1, indicator 1.5

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

dimension.name: Collaboration with Collaboration with Collaboration with

comment.narrative: this value of 4 = 1 water advisory board established (LF indicator 7.1) + 3 new members joined the cooperation (LF indicator 7.2)

dimension.name: Collaboration with Collaboration with Collaboration with

comment.narrative:
08-10-2021: One MoU is signed between all 9 Palestinian partner universities and the 4 Dutch to facilitate and organize work mechanisms. Another MoU is drafted between An Najah University/ Water and Environment Studies Center and business incubators of other partner universities. The aim of the MoU is to create an enabling environment for students after they build their business plans. The role of business incubators is to accelerate the startups through offering the needed business support.
Another MoU is signed between An Najah University (grant holder) and business incubators of partner universities. The MoU aims to institutionalize cooperation between the startups resulting from entrepreneurship training and coaching of students and the package of business incubation services offered by the business incubators.
this is the OKP consortium agreement (LF indicator 6.1)

08-10-2021: The project has started by signing a cooperation agreement between the two leading partners (An Najah and IHE), another cooperation agreement was signed between all Dutch and Palestinian partners. IHE, WUR also provided a support letter for the joint initiative by BZU-ANNU to establish a new PhD programme in the Environmental Engineering and Water Technology department at Birzeit University [BZU] and An Najah National University [ANNU], Palestine. (For MOUs see the report zero)
question raised whether the 3 new members mentioned in LF ind 7.2. for year 3 are 3 new members or the same 3 new members of year 2.

title.narrative: A.S.4. Number of SMEs supported

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The project has started working on students’ entrepreneurship competition. The student can come up with entrepreneurship idea in WASH and CSA. During the process, the entrepreneurship expert will provide a guidance to the students. The project will support for the four best entrepreneurship model for the start-up. The competition process starts by forming a committee to set the competition criteria to be officially announced to students, professors will walk students through their work and get them ready for the competition.

08-10-2021: The project has worked on two parallel tracks towards developing entrepreneurship concepts and practices. The project has worked with TU delft university in developing the professors and administrators' capacities in entrepreneurship, developed the entrepreneurship curricula to teach students, and organized an entrepreneurship competition to help students grasp the learning and acquire the entrepreneurial skills. The competition aims to deliver training, coaching, and mentorship services to student entrepreneurs and alumni of Palestianian universities (Bachelors, Masters, and PhD levels) aiming to establish their startups in the WASH and CSA sectors. The proposed initiative--in conjunction with the Delft Center for Entrepreneurship and a consortium of Palestinain universities and participants--is designed to meet with the following project objectives: ● Increasing awareness of social entrepreneurship through each phase of the program. ● Breaking down theoretical barriers and difficulties in the Arab and Palestinian entrepreneurial environment in general and in the water and agriculture sectors in particular. ● Capacity building for the entrepreneurs, stimulating creativity and promoting the concept of social impact in both design and measurement. ● Offering an extensive curriculum in lean startup, customized mentorship and consultancy, in addition to follow-up and pitch-day preparations. ● Building a virtual community of alumni social entrepreneurs in the water and agriculture sectors. TU Delft with a local consultant BEDAR has developed the concept of the competition, prepared the promotion strategy of the competition, and finalized the application to be posted on universities' websites to reach to the largest number of students. Four Award winners will be declared by the competition event, whose startups will be incubated in the Palestinian universities business incubators for further support after the project ends.

title.narrative: A.E.7. Student satisfaction

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: Students satisfaction has not been measured yet. as COVID-19 pandemic has restricted access to students. the assessment will take place in year 3

title.narrative: A.R.3. Number of relevant innovations

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The project has created a material bank, where all references, training materials, short courses, relevant publications, recorded lectures and videos are located. The bank is accessible to all professors in the 9 partner universities to facilitate and enrich their teaching. The material bank link: https://wesi.najah.edu/en/okp/materials-bank/

title.narrative: A.R.2. Number of relevant publications (level, gender, inclusion)

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The project offered the platform for joint research between Palestinian and Dutch universities to exchange knowledge and experience through research in WASH and CSA. A terms of reference has been developed to organize the joint research willingness between researchers A scientific committee has been established by members of four Palestinian universities, who’s aimed at reviewing the joint proposals applications and supporting research applicants. Four joint proposal applications have been received by the scientific committee from three different universities to be implemented in year 3. The project also offered the opportunity for joint master supervision, three master research thesis have been organized by the project, which will be jointly supervised between Palestinian and Dutch supervisors (PTUK from Palestine, Waginigen University, VU University, TU Delft University)

title.narrative: A.R.1. Number of research strategies/agenda/methodologies revised/strengthened and implemented

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The project offered the platform for joint research between Palestinian and Dutch universities to exchange knowledge and experience through research in WASH and CSA. A terms of reference has been developed to organize the joint research willingness between researchers A scientific committee has been established by members of four Palestinian universities, who’s aimed at reviewing the joint proposals applications and supporting research applicants. Four joint proposal applications have been received by the scientific committee from three different universities to be implemented in year 3. The project also offered the opportunity for joint master supervision, three master research thesis have been organized by the project, which will be jointly supervised between Palestinian and Dutch supervisors (PTUK from Palestine, Waginigen University, VU University, TU Delft University)

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: An Najah University has recently developed a gender policy among the internal policies of its system. An Najah has learnt from the COCA assessment that has been conducted y Nuffic to draft a gender policy to ensure the attainment of gender equality in the organization by redressing the existing gender imbalances. It also provides for equal opportunities for women and men to actively participate and contribute to their fullest ability and equitably benefit from national development. The development of this Policy has been necessitated by a number of donors and international community actors as well as internal forces called for a gender policy stimulating women's participation to combat increasing gender based violence and gender disparities in positions of decision making.

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: Participants in Entrepreneurship have gained the required knowledge in the Business Canvas model that is being offered during the courses they teach, with the local and international examples and cases. The professors were introduced to the water governance framework. Professors participated as students in starting their own project in a direct simulation to learn the challenges faced by their students in the course

08-10-2021: Satisfaction was measured for TMT participants through evaluation after each course. the evaluation measured participants' satisfaction regarding the quality of the training offered, training methodologies and materials shared. Participants varied in their educational levels (senior/ junior) so the level of satisfaction varied as there was No training that could satisfy each and every participant the same way. No scholarships were offered during the project life, and the work with alumni has not stated yet.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

dimension.name: Category of graduates Category of graduates Category of graduates

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: 13 activities have taken place during the reporting period. 36 training and workshop days (288 hours). participants were professors and administrative from all partner universities in addition to PhD and master students. No scholarships have been proposed to Nuffic as per the recommendation of stakeholders and academic institutions.

08-10-2021: The Entrepreneurship training targeted professors from all universities teaching the entrepreneurship courses. There was two female participants only attending e training, as only two female professors teach this course at Palestinian institutions. Out of 22 (20 were Male and 2 Female participants)

B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: Partners need to provide a percentage.

08-10-2021: Post TMT evaluations showed that all participants believe they can apply the learning they received through TMTs. all participants were either professors at universities, or professionals at water and agriculture institutions, or students pursuing higher education. all reported satisfaction wit the quality of the training provided and their applicability to be reflected in their teaching or work place.

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: Since conception phase, the steering committee with the water sector stakeholders have decided not to request funding for scholarships, as there are too many PhD and Master degree holders than the labor market can absorb. They decided that the funding should support capacity building of professors through TMTs and research.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative:
Partners need to provide a percentage not a number for this indicator.
- By 2020, 50 participants will enhanced their capacity in WASH

08-10-2021: The evaluation process that has been conducted after each TMT has indicated that 68.8% of participants acquired new knowledge and skills. Some of TMTs were brand new to participants e.g (SWAP model), (Water Valuation) and some TMTs were familiar to participants. but in each TMT there was an additional value for participants

Partners need to provide a percentage not a number for this indicator.
- By 2020, 50 participants will enhanced their capacity in WASH

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: The project has implemented a number of TMTs where 173 participants have benefited from the training workshops. 16 academics from different universities have been promoted. 9 of them have been academically promoted to associate or full professors, which we believe that the project has contributed to their academic achievements. 6 of them have been administratively promoted to heads of departments, or resumed academic/ administrative roles as coordinators for graduate programs in WASH and CSA. These encouraged more professors to join the TMTs and enjoy the quality learning.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative:
Partners provided the same response for the these:
**A.O.1/B.I.11/B.I.4/B.I.6:** Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the knowledge institution : 20-25 % of staff trained are females
This needs explanation

08-10-2021: The project management has stimulated the engagement of women through the consensus of the scientific research committee to support females' research applications, and give their application the opportunity to win. The project encouraged females' professors and academics to participate in TMTs through emphasizing the importance of participation to the deans and heads of departments.

title.narrative: W.4 People use safe drinking water and adequate sanitary facilities
W.4.1. Number of people trained in WASH

comment.narrative:
08-10-2021: Total 79; 25/54 (f/m) A number of TMTs were conducted to WASH topics have targeted participants from wide range of institutions - The number of attendees were majorly from the partner universities, in addition to participants from stakeholders such as:
- The Palestinian Water Authority (PWA)
- The Water Sector Regulatory Council (WSRC)
- Palestinian Hydrology Group (PHG)
- The Union of Palestinian Water Service Providers (UPWSP)

title.narrative: W.4.2. Number of WASH organisations indirectly strengthened

comment.narrative: 08-10-2021: WASH organizations that will be indirectly benefiting are the municipalities/ water departments. These institutions were trained by Water Regulatory Council and experts from An Najah University trained under OKP. The training was a pilot for 12 municipalities, and expected to scale up next year. Trainees have learnt how to minimize non-accounted for water.
